# List of Latvian submissions for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film

Latvia has submitted films for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film}} since 1992, few months after restoring independence from the Soviet Union. The award is given annually by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to a feature-length motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-English dialogue, and was first presented at the 1956.'s animated film Flow was the first Latvian film to be nominated.]]
As of 2025, only one film was nominated, Gints Zilbalodis's animated film Flow, which won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature.
Submissions
The academy selection committee reviews all submissions for this award, and votes the five candidates via secret ballot voting.
For Latvia, the panel works on behalf of the National Film Centre of Latvia (NFCL). As of 2022, it consists of Latvian Filmmakers Union chairperson Ieva Romanova, Ministry of Culture secretary Dace Vilsone, critic Kristīne Simsone, filmmaker Dace Pūce, film producer Alise Ģelze, and animator Edmunds Jansons. Dita Rietuma, film historian and director of the NFCL, is head of the panel since 2020. They would hold a meeting to decide on the submission, and would often announce the reason for the final decision. Previous members include film historian Viktors Freibergs, director and Latvian Academy of Culture [lv] professor Dāvis Sīmanis, chairwoman of the Latvian Cinematographers Union Zane Balčus, chairman of the Baltic Sea Documentary Film Forum Zane Balčus and Dzintars Dreibergs, as well as film producer Uldis Cekulis.
In 1992, they sent their first-ever film for consideration, a comedy film titled The Child of Man, written and directed by Jānis Streičs, for the 65th Academy Awards. The only director with two submitted films is Viestur Kairish, with The Chronicles of Melanie (2016) and January (2021).
